In contrast, the Occupy Los Angeles protesters, numbering around 2,000, were facing a 5 a.m. deadline to disperse on Monday, November 28, 2011. The protesters, who had been using the "human mic" system of amplification, were ordered to disperse and were warned that they would be arrested if they did not comply. The police, who were armed with batons, plastic handcuffs, and non-lethal weapons, were lined up outside LAPD headquarters. The protesters, who were mostly peaceful, were dispersed, but the police did not clear the park. The Los Angeles encampment, which had been tolerated by the city for weeks, was one of the largest on the West Coast and was part of the 2-month-old national Occupy Wall Street movement. The city had been working to transform City Hall Park, and the protesters were being asked to move to a new location. The protesters, who were mostly peaceful, were dispersed, but the park was not cleared. However, the new evidence suggests that he may have felt a different perspective on the matter. The Russian Orthodox Church, which received the letter, has a position that supports the use of weapons for protection of the Fatherland, but it is clear that Kalashnikov's feelings of guilt were rooted in his personal beliefs.

The AK-47, which is one of the world's most widely used and familiar weapons, has been sold over 100 million times worldwide. Its simplicity and reliability made it easy to manufacture and maintain, but it has also been used by terrorists and child soldiers, which has led to a mix of pride and sadness in its creator. Kalashnikov's work on the rifle was motivated by his experience of the dire lack of weapons in the Red Army during World War II, and he had previously stated that he designed the rifle to defend his country, not to be used in other countries.
answers: In our own obituary of AK-47 inventor Mikhail Kalashnikov last month, we included this quote: The rifle was invented "for the protection of the Motherland," he said. "I have no regrets and bear no responsibility for how politicians have used it." It turns out "no regrets" might not have exactly been true. It contains this line: "I keep having the same unsolved question: if my rifle took away people's lives, then can it be that I ... am guilty for people's deaths, even if they were enemies?" AFP notes that Izvestia ran a copy of the letter, which is typed on Kalashnikov's personal stationery and signed "with a wavering hand." But the BBC notes that it's not clear whether every word came from Kalashnikov: Izvestia reports that his daughter believes a priest helped him write the letter.

However, the real fallout is being felt in the world of advertising. A total of 98 advertisers have informed Premiere Radio Networks, the syndication company that carries Limbaugh's show, that they will no longer advertise on the show or on other programs with similar content. The list includes major companies such as Ford, GM, Toyota, insurance companies like Allstate and State Farm, and restaurants like McDonald's and Subway. These companies have been part of a Premiere memo that was obtained by Radio-Info.com, which outlines the growing exodus of advertisers.

The memo instructs traffic managers to place these companies' ads in dayparts or programs that are free from content that may be deemed offensive or controversial. The list of affected programs includes several other hosts, such as Mark Levin, Tom Leykis, Michael Savage, Glenn Beck, and Sean Hannity. The boycott is a result of the controversy surrounding Limbaugh's attacks on Sandra Fluke, and several of his sponsors have already pulled their ads from his show. The online feed at WABC, his flagship station, is now featuring free public service announcements during his show.

answers: Superbugs such as MRSA are already bad enough. But it turns out that something can make them even nastier: cigarette smoke. Researchers found that antibiotic-resistant bacteria exposed to the smoke became more aggressive and far more difficult to kill, they explain at Eureka Alert. Title: Ending the Harmful Practice of Child Institutionalization: A Global Effort to Eradicate a Cruel Reality

In a world where 8 million children are separated from their families and locked away in institutions, a movement is gaining momentum to eradicate this harm. The charity, Lumos, founded by J.K. Rowling, aims to bring an end to the unjustifiable incarceration of children and replace it with a world where families and communities care for those in need. 

Lumos was born from a powerful image of a caged child, which sparked a sense of shame and a determination to change. The organization's mission is to shed light on the lives of these children, who are often not orphans, but rather children with families that can care for them, or those who are being taken away due to poverty, disability, or discrimination. The shocking truth is that many of these children have parents that can provide care, but due to lack of local education and health facilities, or because of poverty, they are forced to leave their families.

The effects of institutionalization are devastating. Research has shown that these children are more likely to be abused, trafficked, and experience developmental delays, stunting, and psychological trauma. The impact is particularly severe for infants, who are left without the love and attention of a dedicated carer. Damage is done from the start, and it is lasting, with these children returning to the world with their chances of a happy, healthy life severely impaired.

However, the good news is that this is an entirely solvable problem. Based on the successes already achieved in several countries, such as Moldova, the Czech Republic, and Bulgaria, Lumos estimates that the practice of child institutionalization can be eradicated globally by 2050. The solution is not to provide more resources to existing institutions, but rather to invest in inclusive education and health, foster care, and adoption, and to replace the culture of institutionalization with one that prioritizes keeping families together.

International donors play a vital role in this effort, and the issues they choose to fund and the principles they promote can greatly influence what support is available to children and families. Ending the practice of keeping children in institutions makes excellent economic sense, as it is more cost-effective to support a child in a family rather than in an institution. The model works, as shown in the successes of the countries where Lumos has worked, and it is possible that by 2020, the Czech Republic will be without any more children in institutions.

The #Let

Title: New Study Finds Deadly Consequences of "Yo-Yo" Dieting for Those with Coronary Heart Disease

A new study, published in The New England Journal of Medicine, has found that "yo-yo" dieting, or the repeated loss and regain of weight, may have severe health consequences for individuals with coronary heart disease. The study, conducted by Dr. Sripal Bangalore and his team, found that individuals with coronary heart disease who experienced large fluctuations in weight over a period of 4.7 years were at a higher risk of heart attack, stroke, and death compared to those with smaller weight changes.

The study, which involved 9,509 men and women with coronary heart disease, found that the risk of heart attack was 117 percent higher, the risk of stroke was 136 percent higher, and the risk of death was 124 percent higher for those with the greatest weight changes compared to those with the smallest weight changes. The researchers also found a link between weight changes and increased risk of new-onset diabetes.

The study suggests that individuals with coronary heart disease should be concerned about weight fluctuation, and that maintaining a stable weight is crucial to preventing the deadly consequences of "yo-yo" dieting. The researchers recommend that individuals with coronary heart disease should focus on maintaining a stable weight, rather than trying to lose weight repeatedly.

Coronary artery disease, the underlying condition that led to the study, is the most common form of heart disease among men and women in the United States, and it can be caused by atherosclerosis, the buildup of plaque in the coronary arteries. This can lead to atherosclerosis, which can block the blood supply to the heart, resulting in angina or heart attack.

The study's findings are consistent with previous research on the dangers of "yo-yo" dieting, and suggest that this may be a critical factor in the health consequences of this condition. The researchers suggest that further investigation is needed to understand the causes of increased risk with body weight fluctuations and to develop strategies to help Americans keep weight off, rather than having it go up and down.

In a related note, a new study on coronary artery disease suggests that the underlying condition can be caused by a combination of factors, including cholesterol-containing deposits in the arteries and inflammation. The Mayo Clinic notes that a healthy lifestyle can make a big impact in the prevention and treatment of coronary artery disease.
answers: Losing weight is one thing, keeping it off quite another. And now researchers are finding that among those with coronary heart disease (CHD)—which the Mayo Clinic reports develops from damaged or diseased blood vessels typically caused by blockage and inflammation—yo-yo dieting may dramatically increase the risk of stroke, heart attack, and death. Reporting in the New England Journal of Medicine, researchers say they followed nearly 10,000 men and women with CHD between the ages of 35 and 75 for about five years, monitoring changes in body weight and other health outcomes. The takeaway? "It's important to lose weight, but this data says you have to keep it off," lead researcher Dr. Sripal Bangalore at the New York University School of Medicine tells the New York Times. The highest weight fluctuation was on average 8.6 pounds over five years, while the smallest body weight changes averaged closer to two pounds, reports Medical News Today. Those who were already overweight or obese at the beginning of the study and who experienced the highest level of weight fluctuation experienced 124% more deaths, 136% more strokes, and 117% more heart attacks, meaning these CHD patients were more than twice as likely to suffer these negative outcomes in just a few years than people with CHD whose weight only fluctuated two pounds. This doesn't pinpoint a cause, as pre-existing heart problems could be the culprit, but researchers hope to study this correlation further. (Yo-yo dieting is bad for women's hearts in general.)

More screenings for young people might help, but the yield would be low because under-50s are still less likely to get colon cancer. "This would be a big and costly change," says Hendren, who recommends "a lot of research" be done first. (A new killer is expected to top cancer by 2050.)

It was a fundamental right in the United States, enshrined in the first article of the United States Constitution, but was compromised in 2006 when the Military Commissions Act (MCA) of 2006 revoked the right to habeas corpus for anyone detained at Guantanamo Bay and for any foreigner the government detains anywhere and labels an "enemy combatant." The MCA has eroded the very foundation of our legal and constitutional framework, and it has been eroded further by the fact that the government has little or no evidence against many of the men detained at Guantanamo. The overwhelming majority of the men were sold into captivity by Northern Alliance and Pakistani warlords for bounties, and only 10 out of nearly 800 have been charged with any crime. The MCA has created a second-class system of justice, and the government has managed to prevent the detainees from getting a fair hearing in the courts.

This is the first time in U.S. history that an animal has been covered by a writ of habeas corpus, and it could force the university that is holding the chimps to release them. The victim, Markus Austin, 33, was a former member of the Vermont Frost Heaves basketball team and was shot outside his apartment in the parking lot. The shooting occurred on Sunday morning, and police have since issued a second-degree murder arrest warrant for Caballero, 29, who is believed to have boarded a Greyhound bus on Sunday in White River Junction, heading towards New York City.

The motive for the shooting was a dispute that occurred outside the Gusto's bar in Barre, where Austin had been invited to join Caballero and his friends. Caballero's girlfriend, Desiree Cary, 22, was also involved in the altercation and was taken into custody on Sunday evening for unrelated drug charges. The police have reason to believe that Caballero may have fled the state, and are asking for anyone who may know his whereabouts to contact them.

The shooting is the first murder in Montpelier in over 20 years since the 1920s, where a woman shot her husband. The police are working to track Caballero and are using the information that the bus he may have been in was headed for New York City to try and locate him. The police are also reaching out to other states to help track Caballero, and are asking for anyone who may have information about the shooting or the suspect to contact them.

Police in Vermont say they have issued an arrest warrant for 29-year-old Jayveon Caballero, who is accused of fatally shooting Markus Austin in Montpelier early Sunday after an altercation, the Times Argus reports. Witnesses told investigators that Austin, 33, assaulted Caballero’s girlfriend, Desiree Cary, during the altercation outside a bar in the nearby city of Barre early Sunday. Police say Caballero later confronted Austin outside his apartment and shot him dead. The body was found in the parking lot of Austin's apartment complex. A Vermont State Police spokesman says Caballero, who knew Austin before the shooting, fled the town and probably the state after the shooting, WCAX reports. The police spokesman says Caballero is believed to have boarded a Greyhound bus bound for New York City on Sunday morning, which made numerous stops in other states along the way. Later Sunday, Cary, 22, was arrested on apparently unrelated charges of selling heroin and crack cocaine. With around 7,500 residents, Montpelier has the smallest population of any state capital, the AP notes. Police Chief Anthony Facos says this is the city's first murder since a woman shot her husband in the 1920s.

The study also found that the problem is not limited to developed countries, but is also prevalent in developing countries, with two-thirds of the obese population residing in developing countries. The researchers noted that the problem is not just a matter of cosmetic appearance, but rather a serious risk factor for heart disease, stroke, diabetes, arthritis, and certain cancers, with over 3.4 million adults dying from chronic complications of weight each year. The study also found that the problem is getting worse over time, with the number of overweight and obese people increasing at an alarming rate, and the number of children and adolescents with obesity rising nearly 50% worldwide.
